clinical_study.brief_title: Microbiology of Severe Acute Tonsillitis, Peritonsillar Cellulitis, and Infectious Mononucleosis
clinical_study.official_title: Mikrobiologi Ved svær Akut Tonsillit, peritonsillær Phlegmone og infektiøs Mononukleose

brief_summary.textblock: Prospective, observational study of the microbiology of patients referred to a tertiary care center with severe acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar cellulitis, or infectious mononucleosis.

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients referred to tertiary care centers with acute throat infections are most often treated with antibiotics. However, very little is know concerning the prevalent pathogens in patients with acute throat infections without abscess formation. Evidence suggests that Fusobacterium necrophorum plays an important role in complications of acute tonsillitis (e.g. peritonsillar abscess), but also uncomplicated acute tonsillitis.
This study aims to explore the throat microbiology of patients with severe acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar cellulitis, or infectious mononucleosis with a special attention to a possible role of Fusobacterium necrophorum.

primary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of Fusobacterium necrophorum in throat swab cultures

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with recurrent throat infections (questionnaire)
Number of participants without eradication of throat pathogens (throat cultures)
secondary_outcome.description: "Throat pathogens": Fusobacterium necrophorum, Beta-hemolytical streptococci, A. hemolyticum

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with complications of severe acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar cellulitis, and infectious mononucleosis
secondary_outcome.description: "Complications": admission, abscess Development, change of antibiotic treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Prevalence of anti-Fusobacterium necrophorum antibody Development (two-fold or higher increase in antibody level) (blood samples)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: In acute and convalescent sera (day 0 and 14-28)
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of the prevalence of antibody Development (two-fold or higher increase in antibody level) between patients with recovery of Fusobacterium necrophorum in throat swabs versus patients without recovery of Fusobacterium necrophorum in throat swabs

arm_group.description: Patients referred to the tertiary care center with severe acute tonsillitis but without peritonsillar cellulitis, infectious mononucleosis, or abscess formation.
Patients referred to the tertiary care center with severe acute tonsillitis and peritonsillar cellulitis but without abscess formation.
Patients referred to the tertiary care center with acute tonsillitis and biochemical or serological signs of infectious mononucleosis but without abscess formation.
Patients treated for conditions not related to the throat and without signs or symptoms of recent throat disease.

study_pop.textblock: 100 patients with severe acute tonsillitis 100 patients with peritonsillar cellulitis 50 patients with infectious mononucleosis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patients referred to our tertiary care center with acute tonsillitis with or without signs of peritonsillar cellulitis and with or without infectious mononucleosis.
2. Center Score 3 or 4.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Abscess formation.
2. Previous tonsillectomy.
